misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted the problem and implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points in 2D space instead of a grade-to-letter-grade calculator. None of the required behaviors (reading a single numeric grade, checking ranges 90-100, 80-89, etc., and outputting a corresponding letter) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I think Q3 is asking me to write a program that reads coordinates for two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires a program that reads a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, uses conditional logic to check which range the grade falls into (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, below 60), and then prints the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F). It does not involve points or distance calculations.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'Enter x1 and y1' and 'Enter x2 and y2' instead of a single numeric grade.
Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value.
Program computes dx, dy, and uses the distance formula with Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy).
Program outputs 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
No conditional statements are present to map grade ranges to letter grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different assignment (distance between two points) or reused the wrong template file without adapting it to the specified grade-calculator requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite the program so it: (1) reads a single numeric grade from 0 to 100, (2) uses if/else if/else statements to test which grade range the number falls into, and (3) prints only the appropriate letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F). Ignore point coordinates and the distance formula for this question.
related_concepts: Designing conditional logic for numeric ranges
Basic input and output in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, calculations, and output message) corresponds to a distance-between-points problem and none of it relates to reading a grade or computing a letter grade, indicating a complete mismatch with the given specification.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade, showing a mismatch with the grade calculator requirements.
The program uses the distance formula and prints a distance result instead of using conditionals to map a grade to a letter (A-F).

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding Assignment Objective
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code calculating the distance between two points, which is a solution for an entirely different problem, not the required 'Grade Calculator' program. The submission fails to meet any fundamental requirement of Q3, including reading the correct input (a single numeric grade) and implementing conditional logic for letter grading (A, B, C, D, F).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused the assignment requirements and submitted code intended for a 'Distance Between Points' calculation, believing this satisfied the requirements for Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires the program to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if-else) to output the corresponding letter grade based on predefined ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a numeric grade.
The core functionality calculates Euclidean distance.
Lacks any conditional structures necessary for handling grade ranges.
Output message relates to distance, not letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to adhere to the prompt for Q3 (Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the instructions for Q3 (Grade Calculator) carefully and rewrite the program to read a single numeric grade and use if-else statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely correct for calculating distance but completely incorrect for the Grade Calculator problem, indicating a fundamental confusion regarding the assignment's objective.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the wrong topic.
The input mechanism gathers four coordinate inputs, not a single grade.
The logic calculates and outputs distance, demonstrating a failure to implement the required grade calculation logic.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - Distance calculation instead of Grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution for calculating the distance between two points, which is completely different from the assigned Grade Calculator problem. The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file or misunderstood the assignment entirely.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they are solving a distance calculation problem that requires reading two coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computing Euclidean distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges. The problem has nothing to do with coordinate geometry or distance calculations.
symptoms: Program reads four floating-point numbers instead of one integer grade
Program calculates and outputs distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic based on grade ranges
Output format completely different from sample run
Class name 'Q3DistanceBetweenPoints' indicates wrong problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding or misalignment with the assignment specification. The student may have copied code from a different problem or submitted from the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. The task is to create a grade calculator that: (1) reads ONE numeric grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade. Start over with a new approach focusing on conditional logic for grade ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap to the Grade Calculator assignment. The problem statement, sample run, and rubric all clearly indicate a grade mapping task, but the code implements distance calculation instead.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values, not a single grade (0-100) as required

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Outputs distance calculation instead of letter grade. No grade range checking logic present.
Class name explicitly refers to 'DistanceBetweenPoints', indicating submission of wrong solution

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem than the specified grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade and outputs a letter grade based on the given ranges. This indicates a misinterpretation of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes the distance between two points for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read a single numeric grade (0–100) and use conditional statements to map that grade to a letter (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges. It should not compute distances or work with coordinate inputs.
symptoms: Prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a numeric grade
No variables or logic related to grades or letter grades
Computes Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt rather than using if/else to determine letter grades
Output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or reusing code from a different question (distance-between-points problem) instead of implementing the requested grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the inputs and outputs it requires. Before coding, restate the task in your own words (e.g., 'Read one integer grade, use if/else-if to choose A/B/C/D/F, print the letter grade'), then write code that directly implements those steps.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is a standard distance-between-points solution with no references to grades or letter outputs, which strongly indicates the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinate values, computes a Euclidean distance, and prints it, with no reference to grades or letter grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade calculator program. This reflects a complete failure to address the core problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment requested a distance calculation program, or they submitted code from a different (unrelated) assignment for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required creating a Grade Calculator (mapping a numeric grade 0-100 to a letter grade A-F) using conditional logic (if/else if/else).

Output reports 'The distance of the two points is' instead of 'Letter grade:'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt or submitting code from the wrong exercise/question.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the requested task (Grade Calculator). It is a complete misinterpretation or incorrect submission for Q3.

The inputs requested are for geometric coordinates, not a single numeric grade, demonstrating the wrong requirements were followed.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental misunderstanding of assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different program—a distance calculator between two points—instead of the requested grade calculator. This suggests a failure to read and understand the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment asks to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points and output that distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 asks for a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
No conditional logic for grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.)
Output is a numeric distance value, not a letter grade
Class name references 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not 'GradeCalculator'
Uses distance formula Math.sqrt(dx*dx + dy*dy) instead of if-else grade mapping
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read the assignment specification or mixed up two different assignments.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over: (1) Read the input prompt and assignment carefully, (2) Read a single integer grade 0-100, (3) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls in (90-100 → A, 80-89 → B, etc.), (4) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is a complete distance calculator program with no elements of grade mapping logic. The mismatch is absolute and obvious.

evidence.note: Class and input prompts clearly indicate a distance calculator program, not a grade calculator. Asks for coordinates instead of a grade.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Outputs a distance calculation instead of a letter grade. No grade mapping logic (if-else for ranges A-F) present anywhere in the code.
